rows.title: How to do self-care

tool_1_text.eng: Do a 30 second quick relaxation activity.

tool_2_text.eng: Take a moment and think of one thing YOU have done recently that you have done well! Say it aloud if you can: "Well done for …"

tool_3_text.eng: Remember, you deserve your quality time too! What makes you happy?

bottom_text.eng: One-on-one time with your teen can be fun for you, too! It might even make you feel less stressed.

rows.title: How to spend one-on-one time

tool_1_text.eng:
Try to do it every day. 

Find 5 minutes (or more!) each day when your teen does not have something else they want to do.

tool_2_text.eng:
Let your teen choose. 

Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first, but will come to enjoy this time with you!

tool_3_text.eng:
Focus on your teen. 

Switch off the TV and put phones aside. Look at your teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

rows.title: How to praise

tool_1_text.eng: Look for anything your teen does that is helpful or good, and praise them for it. They may not show it, but you will see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

tool_2_text.eng: Be enthusiastic – really mean it when you say it!

tool_3_text.eng: Try to find something to thank them for every day. Even something really small.

bottom_text.eng: You can also praise other adults in your household, too. Notice how they respond!

rows.title: How to give positive instructions

tool_1_text.eng: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.

tool_2_text.eng: Smile, look them in the eye, and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!

tool_3_text.eng: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don’t say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‘please come home by 7pm’ instead of ‘come home in time’.

rows.title: How to manage stress

tool_1_text.eng:
Breathe. Slowly. Pause. 

Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out five times. It will calm you, and give you a chance to think.

tool_2_text.eng:
Share how you feel.

This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry, or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress.

tool_3_text.eng:
Show them you care.

This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say "I understand". It can change everything.

tool_4_text.eng:
Seek the positive.

Can you and your teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?

bottom_text.eng: If all else fails, breathe. You can do this.

rows.title: How to solve problems

top_text.eng: Take a few deep breaths to calm down, and

tool_2_text.eng: Think of possible solutions and what would happen if we used them.

tool_3_text.eng: Choose a solution and try it out.

tool_4_text.eng: Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.

rows.title: How to create rules

top_text.eng: Household rules help keep our teenagers safe, and understand what is expected from them. When you involve a teenager in making rules they are more likely to follow them.

tool_1_text.eng: Household rules help keep our teenagers safe, and understand what is expected from them. When you involve a teenager in making rules they are more likely to follow them.

tool_2_text.eng: Plan rules WITH your teenager. Start with one new rule first – you can add another one later. Discuss the reasons for the rule and listen to their views.

tool_3_text.eng: Praise your teen for planning a rule with you, and praise them for keeping it!

rows.title: How to give calm consequences

top_text.eng: How you introduce calm consequences is important. Remember, when you involve your teen, things usually go better!

tool_1_text.eng:
Check you are both calm. Take a few breaths. Explain to your teen why you are concerned about their behaviour.

Explain the reasons why the rule mattered. You can share your feelings – it is okay to say you are disappointed.

tool_2_text.eng:
Plan consequences with your teen for following and not following the rule.

Ask for their ideas. Talk until you agree on something realistic.

Make a consequence for NOT following the rule and a privilege when they DO follow the rule.

tool_3_text.eng:
**When your teen follows the rule, give praise and privileges!**
They will feel respected and valued. Remember: The more we praise them, the more they will show that good behaviour!

**When your teen does not follow the rule, follow through with the consequence.**
When your teen breaks the rule, calmly give the consequence. This should be FAIR (not too harsh), IMMEDIATE (do it straight away), CONSISTENT (same every time).

rows.title: How to keep your teen safe

title.eng: How to keep your teen safe

tool_1_text.eng: Make maps with your teen of safe and unsafe areas in your community and online. Talk about how to keep their information, photos and videos private online. Talk about how once something goes online, it stays there forever. They might know an example from their friends.

tool_2_text.eng:
Make rules with your teen about how they can stay safe in your community (especially in risky areas that cannot be avoided) and how they can safely use the apps and websites that they like. 

Remember the story about Online Safety? See it again here.

tool_3_text.eng:
Agree on a @global.safety_word. If something happens that makes your teen upset, uncomfortable or scared, they can say the @global.safety_word  and you will help them without getting angry or punishing them, even if they were doing something wrong. 

Remember the story about the @global.safety_word? See it again here.

bottom_text.eng: Digital parenting is just like parenting in the real world. You have taken a BIG STEP to keeping your teen safe in the community AND online. Good for you!

rows.title: How to deal with crisis

top_text.eng: Crisis can make us feel angry or helpless. But this is when our teens really need us to breathe, listen and think.

tool_1_text.eng: Stay calm. Ask yourself "What does my teen need right now?"

tool_2_text.eng: Tell them you are there for them and love them.

tool_3_text.eng: Talk with your teen. What might help the situation? You might need to make immediate plans now, and then long-term plans later.

bottom_text.eng: You can be proud of yourself for exploring ways to get help!

rows.title: How to support each other

tool_1_text.eng: Keep meeting regularly to give each other parenting support.

tool_2_text.eng: Be ‘parenting buddies’ to call when you are upset or do not know what to do.

tool_3_text.eng: Text each other every week to share what you have done well.

tool_4_text.eng: Share @global.parent_app and help other families start their journey.

rows.title: How to talk about sensitive topics

title.eng: How to talk about sensitive topics

top_text.eng: Discussing body changes and intimate relationships can be uncomfortable, but it is so important in order to keep your teen happy, healthy and safe.

tool_1_text.eng:
Build a strong relationship with your teen by spending time with them and showing them you trust them. Create a safe, encouraging space, and avoid judging them.

That will make your teen share their questions and worries with you, when they need advice or are in a potentially dangerous situation.

tool_2_text.eng:
Your teen may feel scared, so as parents we need to start the conversation on body changes and intimate relationships.

Start young (before 9 years) by answering their questions in a simple, accurate way. That builds your and your child’s confidence.

It is okay to feel uncomfortable. Be open, use the correct words, and get more information for yourself if you do not have all the answers.

tool_3_text.eng:
Your teen will get information about sex from many different sources. When they feel safe and comfortable with you, you can guide them and build their ability to find good information and solutions now and in the future.

Help them think about the consequences of behaviours (without shame or blame). Make sure they understand that they should never feel pressured (or pressure someone else) into any sexual activity or relationship.

Get help or information for yourself from other adults or medical professionals.

rows.title: How to stay safe

top_text.eng: In a dangerous situation, we may not know what to do and freeze – this is normal. These tools can help you and your teen stay safe.

tool_1_text.eng:
Know the difference between healthy and unhealthy relationships. If you are attacked, know that it is never your fault. You are allowed to say and do what is needed to stay safe and get away – do not worry about what others may think.

You are worth being defended. You are strong and powerful.

tool_2_text.eng:
When someone makes you (or someone else) feel uncomfortable with what they say or do, that is never okay! We all have the right to feel safe, especially at home.

See the warning signs and follow your intuition. When you feel attacked with words or actions, your goal is to get away.

tool_3_text.eng:
Your voice can stop many attacks. Yell ‘No!’, call for help, warn of consequences, name the behaviour, act crazy, pretend to go along to buy time, use humour, calm them down, or negotiate. 

Be clear, confident and direct. Speak using your voice, body language and eye contact.

tool_4_text.eng:
When our voice is not changing the situation, we can use our bodies.

Know the ‘weapons’ on your body and know the ‘targets’ on your attacker’s body. Use what is free on your body that you can fight with and what is open on the attacker’s body to hit.

bottom_text.eng: If you do get hurt by someone, remember it is never your fault. Ask someone you trust for help, and make sure your teen knows they can tell you anything so you can find a solution together.

rows.title: How to cope with grief

tool_1_text.eng: There is no correct way to respond to grief and no timeline for it to end. It is different for everybody. This is okay. Do what feels right for you and your child.

tool_2_text.eng:
Some people hold a ceremony or have a special meal to celebrate the person and say goodbye.

It can help to make a box of memories to put things that remind them of the person.

tool_3_text.eng: It can help just to talk about the person when you think about them or write down how you feel.

rows.title: How to help your teen learn

title.eng: How to help your teen learn

top_text.eng: Here are some essential tools to help your teen learn.

tool_1_text.eng: People learn better when they learn with others. Spend time with your teen and let them learn with you. When you do activities together, you give them space to learn, make mistakes and ask you questions.

tool_2_text.eng: Your teen will learn from you if they know you support them. Let them try things without shouting at them. This helps them “learn how to learn”, because they feel safe with you.

tool_3_text.eng: Praising your teen is a powerful way to help them try again. Teens do not get things right the first time and should learn how to try again. Praise them for trying to do things, so they can learn from their mistakes.
